subs.text: May 16

@KiarKini @chumak_iryna @britinvan @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock The Russian ‘Federation’ can fail, but the pieces could still prosper.

(Agreed that a failed, but intact, Russia would be a disaster on many levels.)

Self-determination is an essential human right.

Central management from Moscow has failed _multiple_ times over the centuries.

subs.text:
@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock Putin is not as strong as he once was.

He allegedly has health issues.

The republics don’t have to beat him any more, they just need to plan and wait.

With the current economic issues (and the army decimated), the resulting power vacuum will cause regions to just drift away.

subs.text:
@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock What holds this vast, culturally diverse, federation together?

Is it just fear*, tradition, and inertia? Perhaps a little economics? Will that suffice for the next few months/years/decades?

What will Russia look like in 2122?

(* of Putin, the police, the army, or the unknown)

subs.text:
@johngineer @TrentTelenko Vendors have an incentive to over-state capabilities.

Militaries have an incentive to under-state capabilities (or to over-state for deterrence, a-la Reagan’s ‘SDI’/‘Star Wars’ or DPRK and Russia).

🤷

Actual field performance depends on many factors, and is likely classified.
subs.rawText:

🤷

Actual field performance depends on many factors, and is likely classified.

subs.text:
@bbcanuck23 @TrentTelenko They are single-use small ‘pads’ or bags seen tiled on the perimeter of some tanks.

Filled with explosives (a ‘shape charge’, I imagine, to direct energy outward), they explode when penetrated by a projectile (or jet from an anti-tank ‘HEAT’ round) to try to deflect the attack.

@PLCount @1twittafae @kevin_cracknell @TheStudyofWar … and even those shaded areas may or may not be occupied by any significant force, depending on the day.

Due to heavy use of ranged weaponry (‘long-range fires’, as the kids say), one would have to shrink nearly all of those borders by some number of kilometers to find troops.

subs.text:
@EntierSpectre @kamilkazani It’s nice to know that some nations prioritize infrastructure.

Since road maintenance (or any maintenance - see also urban trash pickup contracts) isn’t ‘sexy’, and since government (and the press) generally don’t tend to have experience in those fields, graft is seldom noticed.

subs.text: May 15

@kamilkazani Other possibilities?

 - Z is a ‘sharp’, ‘warlike’ shape with no soft edges like in ‘з’. Likewise with ‘V’/‘В’.

History: “Only the form ꙁ was used in the oldest ustav writing.”

“The shape of the letter originally looked similar to a Greek Zeta with a tail on the bottom (ꙁ).”
subs.rawText:
@kamilkazani Other possibilities?

 - Z is a ‘sharp’, ‘warlike’ shape with no soft edges like in ‘з’. Likewise with ‘V’/‘В’.

History: “Only the form ꙁ was used in the oldest ustav writing.”

“The shape of the letter originally looked similar to a Greek Zeta with a tail on the bottom (ꙁ).”

subs.text: May 14

@Bear_Faced @ClavdiaMinor @sentdefender The compartment where the fire victims were found was not nearly completely flooded, right?

As memory serves, there were three(?) major fatal events (the initial explosion, secondary explosions several minutes later (that killed most crew), and only hours later the fire).
subs.rawText:
@Bear_Faced @ClavdiaMinor @sentdefender The compartment where the fire victims were found was not nearly completely flooded, right?

As memory serves, there were three(?) major fatal events (the initial explosion, secondary explosions several minutes later (that killed most crew), and only hours later the fire).

subs.text:
@moscow_english @sentdefender It’s not _that_ small of an area.
  They’d all fit in a large-sized harbor.

The Black Sea is has a _surface area_ of 168,500 mi², equal area to a square 410 miles on each side.

(i.e. 436,400 km², equal area to a square 660 km on each side)

Also, submarines operate in 3D space.
subs.rawText:
@moscow_english @sentdefender It’s not _that_ small of an area.
  They’d all fit in a large-sized harbor.

The Black Sea is has a _surface area_ of 168,500 mi², equal area to a square 410 miles on each side.

(i.e. 436,400 km², equal area to a square 660 km on each side)

Also, submarines operate in 3D space.

subs.text: @Bear_Faced @ClavdiaMinor @sentdefender Yes, but if poor maintenance practices had not lead to that fire (oily bilge water causing self-ignition of chemical oxygen generator cartridges, if I recall correctly), those crew members could have survived until rescued.
subs.rawText: @Bear_Faced @ClavdiaMinor @sentdefender Yes, but if poor maintenance practices had not lead to that fire (oily bilge water causing self-ignition of chemical oxygen generator cartridges, if I recall correctly), those crew members could have survived until rescued.

subs.text: May 13

@Bill_Abely @brandonazheng @Noahpinion “They” has long been a default when it is not known what pronoun to use; e.g.:

A: “Someone broke into my car last night.”
B: “That’s horrible! Did they steal anything valuable?”
A: “No, that almost makes it worse. They broke two windows for nothing!”
B: “I hope they get caught!”
subs.rawText:
@Bill_Abely @brandonazheng @Noahpinion “They” has long been a default when it is not known what pronoun to use; e.g.:

A: “Someone broke into my car last night.”
B: “That’s horrible! Did they steal anything valuable?”
A: “No, that almost makes it worse. They broke two windows for nothing!”
B: “I hope they get caught!”

subs.text:
@jprupp @FreightAlley @EricRego8 I’m sure it can be flown in to airports without pipelines, but no idea what that adds to the cost.

Does anyone know how western USA airports (especially in land-locked ones) get their fuel deliveries? 

Thinking of places such as MSP, SLC, DEN, BOI…

… oh, right… rail. 🤦

subs.text: @jprupp @FreightAlley @EricRego8 As often is the case, the futures markets know what’s coming before us mere mortals (back to using Diesel fuel as an example): Most airlines pre-purchase or otherwise hedge their fuel, as likely do militaries. Spot price purchases at the local FBO are at ones own peril. [link]
subs.rawText:
@jprupp @FreightAlley @EricRego8 As often is the case, the futures markets know what’s coming before us mere mortals (back to using Diesel fuel as an example):

Most airlines pre-purchase or otherwise hedge their fuel, as likely do militaries. Spot price purchases at the local FBO are at ones own peril. https://t.co/1wg1BAu9oC

@AbeFromanSox @ExtremelyTrains @RickPalaciosJr Homebuilding remains incredibly labor-intensive and resistant to automation.

subs.text:
@Gigi_MCal @jprupp @FreightAlley @EricRego8 It’s a complex system.

  The individual players operate on incomplete information. 

    (example: refinery A sees excess capacity elsewhere in the market and decides not to expand, not knowing that some of that capacity is scheduled to go offline in 3-10 years)

1/

@Bradorado1 @whitemice @ExtremelyTrains @RickPalaciosJr Smaller ranch style homes often necessitate more yard space to compensate for reduced indoor space (think: kids playroom vs yard swingset).

More yard space means fewer lots / acre for the developer, which also lowers profits.

@slamastack The only safe tech for this sort of thing is legacy, open-standard tech such as #X10 or #Insteon and the modern (but much more complicated) #Zigbee or proprietary (#Zwave) equivalents.

Worst-case, a hub might have to be replaced. My X-10 switches from the mid-90s still work!

@DrKateJMiller @NatMorson My ADHD brain would probably have done great as a farmer in a pre-industrial world… and likewise thrived in the strict structure of the military (as long as I was on duty).

In the world in which we live, though, it needs medication (until better treatments are discovered).

subs.text:
@DrKateJMiller @CanadianKayMD I’ve heard that until a decade or so ago, the common belief was that it was something kids outgrew by adulthood, so diagnosis was rarely sought or offered.

It’s probably _vastly_ undiagnosed in people currently over age 30, and even more so for people over age 50.

subs.text:
@nicholrr @TrentTelenko DD-459 was sunk at Guadalcanal.

DD-724 was built two years later, and was also a former USS Laffey.

DD-724 is the museum ship in SC next to the former USS Yorktown*.

(That is CV-10, which itself was a replacement for an earlier ‘Yorktown’, CV-5, that sank at Midway).
subs.rawText:
@nicholrr @TrentTelenko DD-459 was sunk at Guadalcanal.

DD-724 was built two years later, and was also a former USS Laffey.

DD-724 is the museum ship in SC next to the former USS Yorktown*.

(That is CV-10, which itself was a replacement for an earlier ‘Yorktown’, CV-5, that sank at Midway).

subs.text:
@lithohedron @boondaburrah @errantambition @Foone They’re still used by expensive lab hardware such as oscilloscopes, and also in some military equipment.

If you need to quickly move a 50kB file between two air-gapped systems from different vendors, these can be faster, more secure,& lower-overhead than using a USB flash drive.
subs.rawText:
@lithohedron @boondaburrah @errantambition @Foone They’re still used by expensive lab hardware such as oscilloscopes, and also in some military equipment.

If you need to quickly move a 50kB file between two air-gapped systems from different vendors, these can be faster, more secure,& lower-overhead than using a USB flash drive.
